10.text: To survive in this high pressured, crazy world,

14.text: most of us have to become highly adept at self criticism.

18.text: We learn how to tell ourselves our froth failures

21.text: and for not working hard or smart enough.

23.text: But so good are we at this

25.text: that we are sometimes in danger of falling pray

28.text: to an excessive version of self criticism.

30.text: What we might call self flagellation,

33.text: a rather dangerous state which just ushes in depression and under performance,

38.text: we might simply lose the will to get out of bed.

40.text: For those moments, we need a corrective.

43.text: We need to carve out time

45.text: for an emotional state of which many of us are profoundly suspicious:

51.text: We're suspicious because that sounds horribly close to self-pity.

54.text: But because depression and self-hatred are serious enemies of a good life,

59.text: we need to appreciate the role of self-care

62.text: in a good, ambitious and fruitful life.

66.text: To this end, we can perform what we've called a self-compassion exercise:

70.text: a structured meditation lasting fifteen minutes or so,

74.text: lying in bed or perhaps a bath,

76.text: turn over your sequence of thoughts that interrupt and correct the flow of your worst self-accusations.

83.text: For a time adopt an entirely kindly perspective on your setbacks.

88.text: The self-compassion exercise goes like this:

96.text: we're so in love with success

98.text: we fail to notice the scale of the challenges we routinely set ourselves.

103.text: There is nothing remotely normal about what we've tried to achieve.

108.text: We failed, but given the mountain we were trying to climb, the conclusion doesn't have to be that we're simply fools.

121.text: We have tricky family histories, we all do.

124.text: There were things, which happened to us at the hands of others, which can help to explain some of our current troubles.

131.text: We are not entirely sane or well, but none of us are.

135.text: We weren't well set up to carry out certain tasks,

139.text: it isn't wholly our fault in the here and now.

146.text: From the media you'd think everyone was rich and famous and successful,

151.text: but in reality undramatic, quiet failure is by a huge margin the statistical norm.

158.text: We should't tear ourselves apart for not managing to beat what were, in truth, awesome odds.

169.text: Tough self-critical people don't allow themselves the indulgence of believing in luck:

177.text: they think winners make their own luck, but they don't, for the most part.

182.text: Luck is a genuine feature of existence.

185.text: We're robbing ourselves a fair consolation by believing that we're entirely in control and, therefore, entirely to blame when we crash.

201.text: You are not only your achievements,

203.text: status and material success are one bit of you,

207.text: but there are others as well.

209.text: Those who loved you in childhood knew this and in their best moments helped you to feel it.

214.text: Rehearse the internalized voices of all those who have been kind to you,

218.text: pave in the memory of a love

231.text: It seems it will never end:

233.text: that's not the truth, it's just how a crisis feels.

237.text: You need to reduce expectations to zero for a time,

241.text: take each new hour as it comes, and

244.text: without being banal: what you need for most of all is some rest.
